author: parithosh
content:
because its a very hard problem to know how the entire networking stack + nodes running on mainnet will behave. Predicting it months in advance is even harder. So even if we test devnets (irrespective of size) with 72 blobs, it doesn't give us a 100% certainity mainnet will run at that throughput - it just gives us an educated max value. Additionally mainnet runs things like DVT, middlewares, varied types of networking equipment/hosts/orchestration tools - all adding subtle variations to the throughput. 

The safe way to scale is to make changes, collect data and asses how the network reacted to the scale and to continue scaling. BPOs allow us to do this while maintaining the ability to cancel an upgrade.

author: raulvk
content:
it's pretty common in engineering and the software to roll out changes progressively when introducing architectural redesigns to critical systems. yes, you can spend months and months trying to increase confidence and attempt to perfectly capture all variables, only to discover that you missed a small case that ends up playing out in production. because er.... we're all humans. and you need to balance this pursuit of perfection against actually shipping something meaningful *in time*.

now, mapping this to PeerDAS and BPOs. PeerDAS is a massive architectural change from the p2p standpoint. we are testing every happy and unhappy scenario we can imagine (and everyone is welcome to contribute scenarios), but we'll never get to perfection in testnets to reproduce the *exact* p2p mainnet networking conditions so that everyone feels comfortable shipping with 48 or 72 blobs out of the gate.

so from that standpoint, it's more practical to ship the redesign, keep the capacity equal, ensure all looks nominal, and increase the count incrementally. lather rinse repeat.

author: parithosh
content:
To clarify, the plan was to ship multiple BPOs at once. i.e, Fusaka + BPO1 + BPO2 would be shipped in one release. The staged increase would give us a period of time between each activation to collect data. The first two increases are meant to be minor, so that we can validate: Fusaka as a fork and p2p changes, increase 1 and its effects, increase 2 and its effects. We then analyse everything and decide what the new headroom and margins are. We then decide how many BPOs to ship and what new ceiling we are comfortable with. 

To me this is strictly better and requires less on-call devops work than shipping fusaka with a 2-3x blob increase without any real data. the chance of breaking mainnet and causing a ton of work to fix is is strictly higher in this approach.

its the same number of upgrades required by the community, i.e: 1.

author: raulvk
content: no one is imply using validators as a standby for live experiments; what we're saying is that there are variables we don't control and that we can't measure reliably in test environments. therefore, we prefer to adopt the safer approach of shipping the new "foundations" (PeerDAS), and _then_ gradually increasing capacity (via BPO) **because** we are confident about the next level.

author: raulvk
content: whether these clients attest to the 1/3 minority block depends on client behaviour. some clients wait until the 4s mark to release attestations (as of today), and they'll pick the heaviest chain. for them to pick your chain as heaviest, you would've had to repeatedly conduct the loop of harvesting 1/3 extra attestations from the majority partition (to sum to yours) to boost your chain's weight. all this while your majority chain is 2/3 empty, so you have less ability to actually sustain the heavier weight. and all of this is only possible until the base fee diverges or a block with a higher blob count (only allowed under the new BPO) appears. at that point the chains will split due to an EL rejection.

author: etan_status
content:
every validator only attests once per epoch. so you only need to harvest 1/3 of 1/32 per slot.
the assumption here is that there is a 1/3 attacker, and that they get the required luck to have all the initial slots after a BPO activation. 
4s should be enough to send someone an attestation, have them req the block from you because they miss it, and send it to them so that they attest for it.
as outlined in my ethmag post, if a lower security assumption is made during BPO activation, that could also be a resolution, it should just be known (the EIP does not list any security impact at all)

author: raulvk
content:
before we consider adding anything to the security considerations (i'm happy to, once we finish characterizing this), can we align on assumptions? i don't think the ones you list are complete. 

if the goal is to harvest attestations to justify a checkpoint on the minority chain, like i said above, you'd also need the chains to not diverge due to base fee and blob count during the epoch, which makes this even more implausible.

also, those 1/3 of 1/32 are not fungible, so you'd need to specifically target and mislead concrete attesters that are up for attester duty in every slot. it requires extensive planning and sophistication. we can dive into the exact p2p mechanics, but a priori it seems implausible (especially under the timing constraints).

all this while you need to sustain the weight of the alternative chain over the majority chain. if you happen to be the proposer for the next 32 slots, yeah, sure, you can do that, as long as you produce post-BPO compliant blocks. at which point... do we really have a problem?

author: pawandhananjay
content:
we don't recurse beyond the finalized checkpoint.  if we get a block that conflicts with finality, then we drop the chain. So its essentially min(finalized, current-32). The mechanism is mainly to protect from someone feeding us a bogus chain and waste resources on it. 
If it goes beyond 32, we switch to range sync and feed everything to fork choice and let it figure out the canonical chain
